sentiment_score_definition: x <= -0.35: Bearish; -0.35 < x <= -0.15: Somewhat-Bearish; -0.15 < x < 0.15: Neutral; 0.15 <= x < 0.35: Somewhat_Bullish; x >= 0.35: Bullish
relevance_score_definition: 0 < x <= 1, with a higher score indicating higher relevance.

feed.title: TMC Stock (NASDAQ: TMC) Slides 10% Into Year-End Weekend as NOAA Deep-Seabed Mining Timeline Takes Center Stage
feed.summary: TMC, The Metals Company Inc. (NASDAQ: TMC), saw its stock slide over 10% on Friday into the year-end weekend, amidst thin holiday trading and a renewed focus on the U.S. regulatory timeline for deep seabed mining. The NOAA's announcement of a public comment period and virtual hearings in January 2026 for deep seabed mining exploration licenses is creating a time-specific catalyst that investors are closely watching, highlighting the stock's event-driven nature. Despite analyst targets suggesting potential upside, the significant dispersion in these targets and meaningful short interest underscore the high uncertainty surrounding the pre-revenue company's path to commercialization, which hinges on regulatory approvals and financing.

feed.title: What to Know Before Buying The Metals Company Stock
feed.summary: The Metals Company (TMC) aims to extract polymetallic nodules from the Pacific Ocean, which contain critical battery metals like nickel, copper, cobalt, and manganese. Despite a potential project value of $23.6 billion, TMC is currently pre-revenue and faces significant regulatory hurdles as the International Seabed Authority has not finalized deep-sea mining rules. Investors should consider TMC a speculative play due to its financial losses and the uncertainty surrounding commercialization approval.

feed.title: TMC’s Earnings Surprise: What’s Next?
feed.summary: TMC the metals company Inc. reported an unexpected Q3 loss per share of $0.46, significantly higher than the estimated $0.06, with no revenue. Despite a substantial cash reserve of over $115M, the company recorded a $184M loss from operations, creating a mixed financial picture. Investors are left to decide whether TMC's cash position offers a path to renewal or if its mounting losses indicate deeper issues.

feed.title: The Metals Company Posts $23.6B Project Value, 51Mt Reserves | TMC Stock News
feed.summary: The Metals Company (Nasdaq: TMC) reported Q3 2025 results, demonstrating strong project economics with a combined NPV of $23.6 billion and a PFS NPV of $5.5 billion for NORI-D, alongside 51 Mt of probable mineral reserves. The company aims for commercial production by Q4 2027, provided it secures the necessary permits, and has successfully produced battery-grade manganese sulfate at bench-scale. Despite a net loss of $184.5 million due to non-cash items, TMC maintains adequate liquidity and highlights positive regulatory developments for deep-sea mining.

feed.title: The Metals Company Announces Third Quarter 2025 Corporate
feed.summary: The Metals Company (TMC) announced a conference call for Thursday, November 13, 2025, to discuss third-quarter 2025 financial results and recent corporate developments. The company, a developer of critical metals from seafloor polymetallic nodules, aims to supply metals with net positive impacts and work towards a metal commons. The webcast will be available for replay on their website.

feed.title: The Metals Company Subsidiary Submits Largest Deep-Sea Environmental Data Set Yet to International Seabed Authority
feed.summary: The Metals Company (TMC) subsidiary NORI has submitted its largest deep-sea environmental data set to the International Seabed Authority (ISA). This comprehensive dataset, gathered over a decade, includes extensive biological occurrences, seafloor images, and time-series data, forming the basis for NORI’s Environmental Impact Assessment for an exploitation contract in the NORI-D area. TMC believes this data will demonstrate that deep-sea nodule collection is a less impactful way to source critical metals compared to land-based mining.

feed.title: TMC the metals company (TMC) Falls 9.7% as Firm Plans 40 Million New Shares Issuance
feed.summary: TMC the metals company (TMC) saw its stock fall by 9.7% on Thursday due to plans to issue 40 million new shares, which could dilute existing stock. The company also reported a significant widening of its net loss in the second quarter to $74.3 million. Shareholders have approved the new share issuance under its 2021 Incentive Equity Plan for employee compensation.

feed.title: TMC Investors Have Opportunity to Lead TMC the metals company Inc. Securities Fraud Lawsuit
feed.summary: The Law Offices of Frank R. Cruz announces a securities fraud class action lawsuit against TMC the metals company Inc. for investors who suffered losses between May 12, 2023, and March 25, 2024. The lawsuit alleges that TMC failed to disclose deficient internal controls and inaccurately classified the sale of future revenue, thereby misleading investors.

feed.title: The Metals Company Provides Third Quarter 2024 Corporate Update
feed.summary: The Metals Company provided a corporate update and financial results for Q3 2024, highlighting approximately $63 million in liquidity and a net loss of $20.5 million. The company announced a registered direct offering of $17.5 million and set June 27, 2025, for its ISA exploitation application submission. TMC is also expanding its strategy to include a services business for seafloor resource development and diversifying its resource portfolio.

feed.title: The Metals Company Sweeping Sea Bed for Battery Materials
feed.summary: The Metals Company (TMC) is developing technology to harvest polymetallic nodules from the Pacific Ocean for electric vehicle battery materials, despite facing financial challenges and regulatory hurdles. The company plans to use a deep-water drill ship and robotic collector to extract nickel, manganese, cobalt, and copper, with commercial collection pushed back to mid-2026. Environmental groups oppose deep-sea mining due to potential ecological impacts, though TMC argues for its necessity in the transition to lower-carbon energy.

feed.title: The Metals Company processes deep-sea polymetallic nodules
feed.summary: The Metals Company (TMC) has begun processing 2,000 tonnes of deep-sea polymetallic nodules in Japan at its partner PAMCO's Hachinohe facility. The company successfully produced approximately 500 tonnes of calcine from 1,200 tonnes of nodules and will now proceed to smelt the calcine into a high-grade nickel-copper-cobalt alloy and manganese silicate. This marks the world's first commercial-scale processing of these nodules, following years of development and testing.

feed.title: The Metals Company advances commercial-scale processing of deep-sea nodules
feed.summary: The Metals Company (TMC) and Japan’s Pacific Metals Co. (PAMCO) have successfully completed the first phase of commercial-scale processing of polymetallic nodules, producing approximately 500 tonnes of high-temperature material. This achievement involved heating a 2,000-tonne sample to prepare it for smelting into a high-grade nickel-copper-cobalt alloy and manganese silicate. The initiative is a step towards optimizing TMC's near-zero-solid-waste flowsheet for commercial production, despite ongoing opposition from environmental groups.

feed.title: While private equity firms own 19% of TMC the metals company Inc. (NASDAQ:TMC), retail investors are its largest shareholders with 52% ownership
feed.summary: Retail investors collectively hold the largest stake at 52% in TMC the metals company Inc. (NASDAQ:TMC), signifying their significant influence over management decisions, while private equity firms own 19%. The company's top 25 shareholders own 47% of the company, and insiders have recently sold shares. This analysis highlights the distribution of ownership, including institutional, private equity, private company, and insider holdings, and their potential impact on the company's future

feed.title: Money Talk Radio TMC The Metals Company Inc.'s (NASDAQ:TMC) Craig Shesky-Clean and Economic Mining of Deep Sea Nickel Nodules for the Battery Metals Supply Chain
feed.summary: This article features an interview with Craig Shesky of The Metals Company (NASDAQ:TMC) on Money Talk Radio, where he discusses the company's approach to clean and economic mining of deep-sea nickel nodules for the battery metals supply chain. TMC aims to be the cleanest source of nickel with minimal environmental impact, competing economically with traditional producers. The company focuses on polymetallic rocks from the Clarion Clipperton Zone to power electric vehicles, utilizing a metallurgical process that produces zero solid processing waste.
